fields.description:
At this moment, team variables can be accessed by users with access to repositories that belong to the team and individual user account variables can be accessed by users with access to repositories that belong to that user.

It would be good to be allowed to use _individual account_ variables in _team_ repositories.
fields.summary: Allow using individual account variables in team repositories

fields.description:
If there's a PR on ~30+ files, and especially if you have to review it a few times, after some changes were made

I would like to be able to review individual files. Example:
1. Look at the file one
2. Looks okay, approve it
3. It minimizes and will not automatically maximize unless changes are made to it. Probably also a badge of your approval hangs around it

This way reviewing big requests will be possible, instead of currency "whew, finally scrolled through it"
fields.summary: Ability to review files individually inside a PR

fields.description:
It's clear that constantly toggling some settings is annoying for users, and there are some customizations that certain users require that we don't currently offer. 

We're going to create a menu for users to indicate settings for their pull requests that will remain active for future pull request visits:
 # Ignore whitespace
 # Tab width
 # side-by-side view
 # Red-green colorblind friendly diff colors

  !image-2020-03-22-15-53-49-071.png|width=457,height=360!
fields.summary: Allow users to set global pr settings by default

fields.description:
We would like to have the ability to check the total size of all repositories owned by our personal/team account as:
# With this information we can confirm how much free space we need to keep daily backups
# We need to fill some internal forms with that information
# We can better control the size of our code/applications
fields.summary: Ability to check the total size of all our repositories

fields.description: It would be good to have the ability to prevent users from certain groups from approving pull requests. This is necessary for cases where you want to allow the users to access the pull request, but not approve it.
fields.summary: Add the ability to prevent users from approving pull requests

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Having a Unicode character ([List_of_Unicode_characters|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Unicode_characters]) in the branch name restricts the option to 'Run Pipeline for a Branch' option on the Branch tab.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # have a pipeline defined
 # create a branch with a Unicode character (example 'æ') in the name
 # open branch list in the Bitbucket
 # open more options (three dots) for the branch
 # 'Run pipeline for a branch' option is not there

h3. Expected Results

Should allow running a pipeline from the branch tab.
h3. Actual Results

It doesn't show 'Run Pipeline for a Branch' option with Unicode characters in the branch name.
h3. Workaround

Running Pipeline from Pipelines page:
 # In Bitbucket, choose a repo and go to *Pipelines.*
 # Click *Run pipeline*
 # Choose branch with Unicode character in it, a pipeline, and click *Run*
!Screen Shot 2020-02-26 at 14.37.25.png|width=256,height=145!
fields.summary: Unicode characters in branch name restricts 'Run Pipeline for a branch' option on branch tab

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

At this time, the downloaded artifacts have 600 permission with root ownership as the artifacts are uploaded and downloaded by the agent container, which runs as root, not by the build container.

In such cases, a build running by a user other than root, would not be able to use the artifacts in the next step due to permission issues.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Can be reproduced with:
 # 
{code:java}
image:
  name: atlassian/default-image:2
  run-as-user: 1000

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: build
        services:
          - docker
        artifacts:
          - docker.tar
        script:
          - docker pull nginx:latest
          - docker save --output docker.tar nginx:latest    
    - step:
        name: publish
        services:
          - docker
        script:
          - ls -lR /opt/atlassian
          - docker load --input docker.tar
          - docker images
{code}

h3. Expected Results

The users with UID 1000 should be able to access the file 'docker.tar' in the second step.
h3. Actual Results

The users with UID 1000 fails to access file 'docker.tar' in the following command.
h3. Workaround

{color:#172b4d}To work around this{color}, you can change the permission of 'docker.tar' in the first step as shown below:
{code:java}
     ...
         - docker save --output docker.tar nginx:latest 
         - chmod 604 docker.tar       <===== Please add this line
     ...{code}
fields.summary: Downloaded artifacts to have `rw-rw-rw-` permission so they're always readable by whatever user is running in the build container.

fields.description:
Currently, on the branch permissions page, you can only set a preset array of values on the merge checks, as they are dropdowns:
 !Screen Shot 2020-02-26 at 16.46.23.png|thumbnail! 

This feature request is to change the dropdowns to be textboxes so that you can add any value you want.
fields.summary: Change branch permissions merge checks from dropdowns to textboxes

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The new Pull Request page shows `0 builds` on the right panel even if the latest commit does have a build status associated with it. This only happens for repositories with non-Pipelines CI systems, that have been set up to post build statuses on Bitbucket.

The build statuses are shown correctly on individual commits and branches and pull requests list shows the build status icons.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add a build status to a commit using [Bitbucket API|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/commit/%7Bnode%7D/statuses/build]
 # Create a pull request including the commit with the build status

h3. Expected Results
New Pull Request page shows `1 build` on the right panel.

h3. Actual Results
New Pull Request page shows `0 builds` on the right panel.

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: New Pull Request page shows `0 builds` on pull requests with non-Pipelines build status

fields.description:
Currently, when adding new users to the account, being it to a repository or to a group, Bitbucket creates a log in the Audit log page.
The same does not happen when the user is granted access to some group/repository and he/she already is:
* A member of the account OR
* Has access to any repository that the account owns.

We would like to have this information on our account Audit log page as, doing so,  we would be able to keep track of:
# Who granted access to the "X" user and to what content
# Who was added to the "X" repository
# When did the events above mentioned happened
fields.summary: Audit log - Add more granular control of changes on repositories access

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When you use your credentials to authenticate via API, the same logged in credential on UI session gets logged out. This is an intermittent issue and does not happen all the time.

Example : Intermittently making any API request using a credential, the browser session which is logged in via the same user shows "Something Went Wrong". A refresh shows that the account is logged out.
 * The Atlassian Account is still logged in
 * Only Bitbucket Account is logged out.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Login to Bitbucket and open Repository in Source View
 # Create a PR via API Request using same username and password as you are logged in the browser. (POST or GET) - It does not seem specific to PR API, It could be other API as well.
 # Navigate to another view on the Bitbucket UI. Example : on your Bitbucket repository Source View, click Pull Request on the UI, you will see "Something Went Wrong"
 # Refresh the page and see that you're logged out.
 # Click Login and you are redirected back into the account without prompting credentials
 ** This indicates that the Atlassian Account session was still valid as opposed to Bitbucket Account Session

h3. Expected Results
 * Regardless of using the same credential on API request, the UI session shouldn't get logged out

h3. Actual Results
 * User session gets logged out on the UI
 * Console shows the following error :
 * 
{code:java}
{
  "data": {
    "key": "INSUFFICIENT_RIGHTS"
  },
  "type": "error",
  "error": {
    "message": "Access denied. You must have write or admin access.",
    "data": {
      "key": "INSUFFICIENT_RIGHTS"
    }
  }
}
{code}

h3. Workaround
 * There's no direct workaround to this issue.
 * You will have to refresh the page and login once again by clicking the Avatar (bottom left) > Login.
fields.summary: Bitbucket browser session gets logged out when an API request is made using the same credentials

fields.description: Currently, we only support repositories import, it would be great if we can include a Pull request importer as well
fields.summary: Ability to import Pull request from 3rd party git provider

fields.description:
This feature request is to add the ability to, on Pipelines, run multiple steps that perform deployments to the same environment on the same build.

Something like this for example:
{code}
pipelines:
  branches:
    master:
      - step:
          name: Deploying to AWS production
          deployment: production
          script:
            - <myDeploymentScript>
      - step:
          name: Deploying to AWS production using code deploy
          deployment: production
          script:
            - pipe: atlassian/aws-code-deploy:0.4.0
              variables:
                AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: '<string>'
                AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: '<string>'
                AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: '<string>'
                APPLICATION_NAME: '<string>'
{code}

This would allow users to have multiple steps use the same variables defined in the deployment variables section, as well as allow for more organization without needing to group everything into one single step.
fields.summary: Allow to run multiple deployment steps for the same environment on the same build

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

While creating a new branch on the UI, Bitbucket keeps reloading the "Source Branch" list, preventing us from keep typing the name of the branch we are looking for.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # On the left nav bar or, in the branch section of a repository, select Create new branch
 # Type the name of the source branch if there are more than 10 branches with the same prefix, the UI will keep reloading the list almost after each new character that you add to the search.
#* eg. deve(pause)lop(pause)-(pause)1...

h3. Expected Results

The UI should give more time between each new character or either do not prevent new characters from being added while it is loading new results on the branch list.

h3. Actual Results

The textbox freezes and does not allow new characters to be added until the branch list result is completely loaded.

h3. Workaround

Type character by character and wait for the UI to load the list or, copy past the full name of the branch on the "Source Branch" text box.
fields.summary: While creating a new branch on the UI, Bitbucket keeps reloading the "Source Branch" list

fields.description:
As per the title, enable the ability of write access users to create projects on team accounts.

Currently, as per https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/group-repositories-into-projects-792497956.html, only admin users can create projects.
fields.summary: Add the ability to allow users with write access to create projects

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a user is not a Team Administrator, they are not able to view Projects under "https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/projects".

However, when the same user accesses "Team Account > Projects", the list of projects is visible. This is regardless of Private / Public Projects. : [https://bitbucket.org/smartenergystorage/profile/projects]
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new user account.
 # Add user to a Team Account (with only repository permission) and No Team Permissions
 # From user's account access "https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/projects" and you won't be able to see the list of projects.
 # Access "https://bitbucket.org/<Team Account Name>/profile/projects" and you can see the list of projects.

h3. Expected Results
 * User should be able to view the list of projects from the Dashboard view even if they don't have Team Admin permission

h3. Actual Results

User's are not able to see the Projects in the Bitbucket Dashboard > Projects view

Screenshot :

!Screenshot 2020-02-12 at 11.12.43 AM.png|width=306,height=194!
h3. Workaround

The workaround now is to view it directly from the Team > Projects. 
 Alternatively, you can just browse the URL directly with your team workspace ID.
{code:java}
https://bitbucket.org/<workspace_id>/profile/projects
{code}
fields.summary: Non-Team Admins unable to view Projects in Bitbucket Dashboard

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, there is no way to bypass the pre-receive hooks from Jira on Bitbucket cloud repos while pushing any commits on git. Although, this is a mandatory condition after its enabled, it creates a problem when you want to run tests using pipelines. There is no way to bypass the pre-receive hooks and getting an error while pushing without an issue key in the commit message.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Enable pre-receive hooks under links section
 # Create a pipelines YAML to push changes without a commit message with Jira issue key. 

h3. Workaround

User can always toggle on/off the Links manually. 

Under repositories-->settings-->workflow–> Links

*Suggestion*

*C*reating an API to toggle on/off the Links will help the users to run commits without issue keys for testing and re-enable after the testing.
fields.summary: Way to bypass pre-receive hooks under links section

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When you filter the commits and choose a tag it shows all commits rather than the commit that has the tag.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a tag and assign it to a commit. 
 # In the commits page, open the filters option and choose the tag
 # It displays all commits instead of displaying the commit with the selected tag.

h3. Expected Results

Display only the commit that has the selected tag
h3. Actual Results

The full history of the commit associated with that tag is displayed
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When filtering the commits by tag, display only the commit that has the tag

fields.description:
*Issue:*  Users prefer being able to open up an entire file to see all of the code context above and below the diffs rendered in the PR. The new experience doesn't offer.  

*Proposal*: Make it possible for users to trigger a modal that shows the single file in its entirety (up to a certain limit) in either SBS or unified diff mode, along with the comments present on the code itself.

 

*Designed Solution:* 

*1. How to trigger*

!image-2020-03-22-15-38-42-062.png|width=256,height=284!

*2. The Modal View*

*!image-2020-03-22-15-40-01-045.png|width=508,height=289!*

*3. Error State if File is Too Large (temporary solution)*

*!image-2020-03-22-15-41-16-044.png|width=569,height=211!*
fields.summary: View whole file at once in PR

fields.description:
When Bitbucket's PR experience attempts to load PRs, it currently retrieves all files from a PR, and renders them simultaneously on the page. This occasionally overloads the front-end and prevents users from viewing their PRs. 

 

We're going to create a backup mode that loads a single file at a time, just like Bitbucket Server currently does. This will involve adding a new search functionality. 

 

This mode will be triggered for PRs over a certain size automatically, and might possibly be manually triggered as a default setting for users (tbd).

 

related ticket - https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-19952
fields.summary: Implement 'single file mode' for Large PRs
Ability to filter code search by file type only

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
* Avatar does not show up in iOS devices making it impossible for users log out. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log in Bitbucket Cloud in any iOS (mobile) device using Safari or Chrome (didn't have the chance to test with other browsers as well.
 # Try to logout.

h3. Expected Results
* The avatar should show up so the user clicks at it and the *Log Out* option shows up. 

h3. Actual Results
* The avatar is out of the screen and the scroll doesn't work. 

h3. Workaround
* On iPhone you can just change to portrait mode and you can see the
fields.summary: Avatar does not show up in iOS devices making it impossible for users log out.

fields.description:
We would like to have specific groups required to review pull requests based on what is being check-in.

Rules:

SQL scripts (*.sql) requires DBA group review

Terraform (*.tf) requires DevOps group review

All pull requests require someone from Architect group to review

 

Example:

main.cs, main.tf -> Architect, DevOps

main.cs, lookup.sql -> Architect, DBA
fields.summary: Ability to require specific reviewers for a pull request

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Blend/Split/Pixel diff buttons are not working as expected in Old PR view for images diff even for the image of same dimension. A tool tip appears for all three buttons with message- "Split mode image diff is not available because images are not of the same dimension" even if the images are of the same dimension.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Upload an image via a commit
 # Switch to a different branch and upload an edited version of the image via a new commit
 # Create a new pull request
 # Scroll to the bottom to check the image differences in the "Files changed" section.

h3. Expected Results

The "Blend", "Split" and "Pixel diff" buttons should work as per functionality.
h3. Actual Results

The "Blend", "Split" and "Pixel diff" buttons are greyed out.
h3. Workaround

Use new Pull request view and we are making improvements in this.
fields.summary: Image diff functionality in Bitbucket Old PR UI does not work

fields.description: As per the title, this feature request is to change the file downloads to automatically be on the CL/RF used by Windows when on a Windows machine.
fields.summary: Ability to choose CL/RF when performing downloads on Windows

fields.description: Currently, there's no email notification option for a specific file modified/change, it would be great to have one instead of the commits notification which is general.
fields.summary: Ability to get email notification for specific file modification

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In Account settings > "Users on Plan", if the user is *Inactive*, it shows up on that list. This can be confusing as it makes admin's think that user is still being counted against the plan on the account. 

However, the user isn't actually counted against the account plan. 
If you navigate to "Plan Details" in Account Settings, you'll see the correct number of users on plan, which is excluding the inactive users. 

This is more of a UI bug on the Users on Plan view. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a user to a user group in an account which has access to Private Repositories
# Mark that user account as Inactive (probably a *temporary* account deletion to de-activate the account to simulate the scenario)
# Access  "Users on Plan" view and you'll see the same user on the list of users. 
# Access "Plan Details" view and you'll see that the user count is lower than the list of users on "Users on Plan" as it excludes the inactive users.

h3. Expected Results
It's expected to not include to Inactive users on the "Users on Plan" view. This should match the number of users displayed on "Plan Details".

h3. Actual Results
The "Inactive User" is shown in "Users on Plan View"

h3. Workaround
There's no workaround for this View.
fields.summary: Inactive Users still shows up in Users on Plan in Account Settings

fields.description:
Bitbucket Server offers the ability to batch notifications: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/notifications-776639933.html]

It'd be nice to have something similar - a batch or summary of issues for Bitbucket Cloud. 

An example of this:

When someone approves a PR. If someone does approve and then disapproves in rapid succession, it can lead to a bombardment of emails.
fields.summary: Auto bundle email notifications in a short timeframe
Specifying a custom icon in a Bitbucket Connect app doesn't work

fields.description:
I've accidentally deleted comments on a pull request twice within the last week when missing the "Reply" link in Bitbucket Cloud. Would it be possible to add a confirmation dialog to make sure this is what's wanted?

!image-2020-02-19-10-57-39-415.png!
fields.summary: Add confirm dialog before deleting comment

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The bug refers to the old fixed bug: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-6567
If you render a *README.rst* file, it is poorly formatted.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create README.rst file
 # Add the format below
** 
{code:java}
================
Test Header
================

------------------------------------------------------
Some description
------------------------------------------------------

.. contents::

Section 1
========

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut 
labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco 
laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in 
voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat 
non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.
{code}


h3. Expected Results
The contents will be properly spaced or the margins will be well-balanced nicely.

h3. Actual Results
The contents are not properly spaced

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Formatting issue with Restructured text not properly spaced
Branching Model Settings API 2.0 Documentation

fields.description: It'll be great if the Bitbucket Notebook Viewer can allow users to render Notebook files (such as .ipynb files) within the diff view between commits.
fields.summary: Allow Bitbucket Notebook Viewer to render Notebook files in diff view.

fields.description:
Do you think you can add a button that could stop a running pipeline from the pipelines/home#!/results page?
!image-2020-02-19-09-33-48-066.png!
fields.summary: Add a way to stop a pipeline from the pipeline dashboard

fields.description: Currently, we only cache public docker image and it would really be great if we can cache private docker image which reduces the time build took to download the image on every build/steps.
fields.summary: Caching private docker image for build/service container

fields.description:
Currently, we do have an option to ensure that all commits on Bitbucket include on its message a link to a valid Jira issue (eg. BCLOUD-10 Change message), however, the same is not applicable for Pull Requests.

We would like to have this functionality to enforce that the Pull Requests raised on Bitbucket are linked (like the commits above mentioned) to a Jira issue, in order to it to be created.
fields.summary: Ability to enforce Pull Requests to be linked to a Jira issue

fields.description:
It looks like new files don't have files at the end of line rendered in pull requests. That can appear as an error in some projects based on their style guide. 
 
It's probably worth adding a rule to support rendering blank lines at the end of file.
fields.summary: Render blank lines at end of PR files
Button to download git log from Bitbucket UI

fields.description:
First, thank you for adding the ability to create Jira issues right in a Pull Request, when adding comments!

 

Jira issues don't show up on the Project board when we create the Jira issue in BitBucket.  They default to the backlog, so they are not immediately visible. 

I have to manually move them to the Board for them to be visible.
fields.summary: JIRA issues created in Pull Request should go to board, not backlog

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When user sets a side-by-side diff on one file inside a PR, that same file will be shown as side-by-side when opening any other PR in the session. Refreshing the UI or logging back again makes the file to go back to the default state (no side-by-side)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open a PR
 # Click on "Side-by-Side" diff for any file
# Check another PR containing the same file. It will be shown in side-by-side diff

h3. Expected Results
PRs settings should be one per-PR, not overall.

h3. Actual Results
File is shown as selected in the other PR (side-by-side)

h3. Workaround
Refreshing the UI resets the diff configuration and it will be shown plain.
fields.summary: Setting a specific file as side-by-side diff in one PR makes the file to be shown side-by-side on all PRs

fields.description:
This feature request is to add the ability for org admins to restrict managed users from adding marketplace apps to their personal accounts or associated team accounts.

This will provide further control to org admins on their managed users.
fields.summary: Restrict users from installing marketplace apps without permission from the org admin
Wrong destination branch selected when creating branches through Jira
If the user does not have access to the repo, please return a generic error message instead of telling them if repo exists or not

fields.description:
Currently, the Pipeline steps won't allow manual steps to be run if the Artifacts has been expired even when the steps are not using Artifacts. So a user build that passed the 14 days expired artifacts steps no longer allowed to run deployment if their artifacts have been expired.

Suggest that we allowed pipeline steps that are not using Artifacts to be run if the Artifacts has been expired.
fields.summary: Allowed manual steps that are not using Artifacts to be run when the Artifacts has been expired

fields.description:
The feature request is to create structure similar to:
parallel:
   sequential:
      -step
         ...
      -step
         ...
   sequential:
      -step
         ...
      -step
         ...
The reason I need this structure is that steps in each of the parallel streams should use different images for my project.

Thank you!
fields.summary: Possibility to run steps sequentially within different parallel streams in pipelines

fields.description:
For multiple reasons sometimes we need to make a copy of a file and add it to the repo with a different name.

 

For example:

/projects/start_work.cs exists in a Git repo.

/projects/start_work_extended.cs is now added to a Git repo, but it is a modified version of start_work.cs.

 

GIT diff has this syntax as an option:

 
{code:java}
git diff [<options>] <blob> <blob>
This form is to view the differences between the raw contents of two blob objects. {code}
 

In Bitbucket we would like the ability to define in a pull request that a file that was ADDED was derived from a different file already in the same branch, so we should show the DIFF between the original file and the new file that was ADDED for review purposes only.  This would allow us to see what is different from the original file and the new file that was added even though there is no actual history for the newly added file. 

 

This could be implemented as a menu item in the 3-dot menu below "Ignore Whitespace" as "Compare to other file path", and when you choose it you would paste in the relative path in the repo to the file you want to compare it to.  Yes, it would be manual, but it would be a start and very helpful.
fields.summary: Show diff from a different existing file when adding a file

fields.description:
Currently, if someone accidentally pushed a sensitive data or credential tokens, there's no way for the user to know that he/she did.

*Feature request*:
It would be great to have a feature that will scan repositories with sensitive data or credential tokens automatically and email admins or owner of the repository about it.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Cloud Token Scanning

fields.description:
We work with various different companies, and we strictly use IP Address based Access Control.

We noticed that after adding like 5 to 6 IP Addresses, it becomes difficult to remember whose IP it is.

We request team to provide a small text box while adding IP Address, so that we can add a small comment to whom that IP belongs. There is enough space next to IP Address to show such small description.
fields.summary: Add Description field for IP Addresses in Access Controls

fields.description:
When I'm creating a pull request, typed lots of text, added screenshots and whatnot, and someone (or even me) pushes something new to the repository, the pull request creation page shows a modal asking if I'd like to create the PR anyways, or reload with the changes.

I thought reloading made sense, so I clicked. But then I lost *EVERYTHING* I have added on the description field. That's just terrible and frustrating. Lost hours of my work.
fields.summary: Pull request description lost when code's changed and reloaded

fields.description:
This is a feature request for Bitbucket Pipelines.

When building a release, some artifacts are produced. These artifacts are required in the deployment steps. At the moment these artifacts are retained for 14 days.

That means that it is not possible to quickly rollback to a previous version if the release was built more than 14 days ago. Consider the following scenario:
 * A release was built and deployed to production 30 days ago. It has been working perfectly fine all this time.
 * Today, a new release was built and deployed to production. Unfortunately this release contains some problems and shortly after the deployment the team decides to rollback to the previous version which has been in production for the last 30 days.
 * Unfortunately it is not possible to rollback quickly because the necessary artifacts expired 14 days after the initial deployment, even if the release was still deployed in production.

Even for teams that deploy frequently to production, there may be very good reasons the team may want to pause deployments to production for more than 14 days. For example, this may include holidays, priority changes, complex investigations of issues affecting the pre-prod environments, etc. Or the service may just be in maintenance mode.

I understand there is a need to purge old artifacts. The suggestion would be to start the counter not when the release is deployed for the first time, but when the release is removed from the last environment. In other words: purge the artifacts 14 days after the release has not been deployed to any environment. If the release is still deployed in some environments (including production), please keep the artifacts around.
fields.summary: Ability to rollback to previous version, even if deployed 14+ days ago

fields.description:
It'd be nice to have a native official CLI application to use with BB Cloud. 

Similar to [https://github.blog/2020-02-12-supercharge-your-command-line-experience-github-cli-is-now-in-beta/]
fields.summary: Official CLI Application

fields.description:
Currently there is no Bitbucket API endpoint to pull this information. It can either be achieved by cloning the repository locally or checking the information within the UI.

Users use case for this request is to do automations based on repository size or to simply track their repository size.
fields.summary: Create a Bitbucket API endpoint to pull repository size detail

fields.description:
As an user, I would like to be able to login to a single Bitbucket account using multiple email addresses.

This is a quality of life improvement change so that users that have multiple accounts with multiple products don't have to keep switching between accounts.
fields.summary: Allow to log into Bitbucket using an email Alias or Allow to create multiple "primary" email addresses

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The assignee field cannot be populated while assigning issues of Bitbucket issue tracker via APIs
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1:
 Obtain the API from: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/issues]

 
{code:java}
HTTP Method: POST
 Link: https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/cmysoresuresh/personal-01/issues
 BODY: *{"title": "test issue title 20222", "content": { "raw": "test issue description 2021",assignee:
{"username": "testuser"}
, "markup": "markdown" }}*
{code}

2. Step 2
 You will notice that that the issue gets created. However, cannot be assigned to any user.
h3. Expected Results

The assignee mentioned needs to be assigned the issue
h3. Actual Results

The assignee remains empty and the issue is unassigned

h3. Workaround

Assignment needs to be done via the User Interface
fields.summary: Cannot assign users to an Issue over Bitbucket Cloud Issue tracker using APIs

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
- The user is not able to see a snippet that has around 34MB. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Snippet with more them 34MB
 # Try to open it. 

h3. Expected Results
- It should open the snippet or show a proper message saying that it's too big and informing the limit to the user. 

h3. Actual Results
- The user is receiving "Something went wrong" error with a sentry code that doesn't have any relevant information about why the error was thrown.

h3. Workaround
- There's no workaround in place yet.
fields.summary: Users are receiving "Something went wrong" when trying to open a snippet.

fields.description:
As per the title, this feature request is to add the ability to create exportable reports of which developers are added as reviewers, have approved or not, and their comments on specific files in order to make code review auditing easier.

Preferably, this report needs to answer the following questions:
1) How long did the Pull Request took to be merged?
2). Who is reviewing most Pull Requests?
3). Who is adding more comments?
4). Who is responding fastest to Pull Requests?
fields.summary: Exportable report of which developers are reviewing pull requests

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

A user can have two types of access to an account/team:
 1. Access via a User Group
 2. Direct repo access

At the moment, it is possible to remove a user from a User Group via API
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/groups-endpoint-296093143.html]

However, there is no way to remove a user's direct repo access via API.

Some customers would like to be able to remove any type of access a certain user has to their account/team via API, when this user leaves their company.

At the moment this is only possible via the UI, by going to the account/team's Settings > Users on plan, and then remove the user there.
h3. Suggested Solution

Provide a way to remove ALL user access to an account/team via API.
h3. Workaround

At the moment this is only possible via the UI, by going to the account/team's *Settings* > *Users on plan*, and then remove the user there.
fields.summary: Remove all user access to an account/team via API

fields.description:
API documentation: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pullrequests?_ga=2.142334964.735174521.1581324402-978109705.1577156618#post]

 

While creating a pull request manually from Bitbucket UI, it is possible to add all the intermediate committers as reviewers to the pull request by checking a flag, similar flag/option is required (perhaps a Boolean flag) to achieve the same through the pull request API.
fields.summary: Provide an option/flag to add all the committers to the pull request during pull request creation with Bitbucket 2.0 API.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Going to PR page direct while not logged in resulted in a infinite spinner

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open a anonymous browser window
 # Go to a PR page like https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/graphql-gateway/pull-requests/

h3. Expected Results

Some sort of login screen

h3. Actual Results

It spins indefinitely - it never presents a login

I am using the new PR experience BTW

h3. Workaround

None
fields.summary: Going to PR page direct while not logged in resulted in a infinite spinner

fields.description:
We recently moved to ECR hosted images for our pipelines, and given that Bitbucket doesn't support caching of build images unless they are public dockerhub images have noticed a substantial increase in ECR related cross-region traffic costs from pipelines pulling the build image.

We are looking into moving our ECR images into an appropriate region to avoid the cross region costs, but from what I have been able to find pipelines can be executed in either us-east-1 or us-west-1, if that is correct we would be unable to ensure that the pipeline always uses ECR images from the region it is executing in.

In order to solve that it would be useful to combine a pipeline environment variable exposing the region the pipeline is executing in with the feature requested in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-13014 to allow expansion of evironment variable in the image definition for the pipeline.
fields.summary: Expose pipeline AWS region in environment variable

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When transferring a repository whose name has special character like *ö* , we get "Something went wrong" message
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to the repository settings page > Repository details> Transfer repository
 # Enter the workspace ID of the new owner.
 # Click on Transfer button
 # We get "Something went wrong" message
 # If you go back to the previous page, you can see that the transfer request was sent successfully. Hence *there is no impact to the functionality here.*

h3. Expected Results

The error message should not be displayed.

 
h3. Actual Results

The below message is displayed.

!image-2020-02-11-15-52-15-985.png|width=645,height=494!
h3. Workaround

There is no impact to the functionality here. To avoid this issue, change the repository name to remove the special characters like *ö*
fields.summary: "Something went wrong" message appears while transferring a repository

fields.description:
Like we have *Merge checks* in *Branch permissions*, it would be useful if a similar functionality for who should be allowed to *Decline* a Pull Request.

The choices I would be looking for are: 
* Author
* Reviewer

Looking at *Decline* specifically is important as it corresponds to a what-happens-next type of workflow. 

For example:
* Is the issue still relevant?
* Should the ticket be updated with a different priority?
* Mark as `Won't Fix`, etc

This obviously depends on everyone's workflow, but for the above example it would the the Author's responsibility to do the above changes at the same time of Declining the Pull Request.

A similar suggestion can be found here:  [BCLOUD-12509|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-12509?_ga=2.65377710.1230833264.1581337100-292026479.1512951197&error=login_required&error_description=Login+required&state=1efa0cf1-882e-4cdb-b917-332b6411d18b]
fields.summary: Restrict who can decline a pull request

fields.description:
Hi,

We have a specific use-case for the following branch permission: only allow pull requests from specific branch(es).

Our workflow/process desires a linear approach, we would like our pipelines (including deployments) to align with this workflow/process.

Our branches align respectively with our environments (by name). We want all features we develop to travel through these branches (environments) linearly, however, we're not able to set up a policy that enforces this using the Bitbucket branch permissions. 

Making it possible to only allow pull requests from specific branches would fix this.
fields.summary: Branch permissions - only allow pull requests from specific branch

fields.description:
It is an expected behavior to see an error prompt for a user with just 'read access' who tries to trigger pipelines on public/private repository.

The following error prompt is shown when the pipeline is triggered from a branch or a commit page:

!Screen Shot 2020-02-10 at 20.06.49.png|width=356,height=95!

This is not consistent when a pipeline is triggered from the Pipelines tab using the 'Run Pipeline' button as it doesn't show the same prompt. It loads indefinitely and fails after some time:

!Screen Shot 2020-02-10 at 20.08.45.png|width=322,height=153!

That said, the functionality is intact as it doesn't allow anyone with 'read access' to trigger a pipeline. Thus, treating this as a feature request and not a bug.

But, it would be great to have a consistent error prompt for all the different methods of triggering a pipeline.
fields.summary: Inconsistent behaviour in prompting error while triggering pipeline with read access from pipelines tab and commit/branches page

fields.description: At this moment, when accessing one account Bitbucket shows a repository last updated date. It would be good to have the repository creation date on the list too.
fields.summary: Add repository creation date to repositories list

fields.description: As a user, I would  like to be able to configure the directory's name to which the pipeline clones the directory to. Currently it always clones to "/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build" and setting the $BUILD_DIR variable doesnt seem to work. Some of our tests use functionality that requires the root directory of the cloned repository to be the same name as the repository, ie. "/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/http_app".
fields.summary: Make it possible to define the directory to which a pipeline clones the directory to

fields.description:
Some users would like to be able to create custom merge checks for Bitbucket Cloud, either for integrations like Code Reports, or for developers to write their own custom merge check modules.

ex. 

* [Link|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/bitbucket/tutorials-and-examples/controlling-when-pull-requests-can-be-merged/?utm_source=%2Fbitbucket%2Fserver%2Fdocs%2Flatest%2Ftutorials-and-examples%2Fcontrolling-when-pull-requests-can-be-merged.html&utm_medium=301]

Update:
* Possibility to add branch restrictions to tags, making it possible to both:
*# Set if it is necessary to have a given tag pattern 
*# Set how deep on the last commits the tag needs to be
fields.summary: Create custom merge checks / branch restrictions

fields.description:
When I'm reviewing code, I like to have as much of the vertical space as possible.

Please allow an option to hide the Approve, merge, and other options.

Those are usually things I need to do at the end of the review, not during. So having them visible all the time feels unnecessary.

 

Thanks, otherwise the new design works well.
fields.summary: Give me back the top part of the screen (No reviewers, Approve, merge, ...)

fields.description:
According to https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/use-docker-images-as-build-environments-792298897.html, atlassian/default-image uses version python 2.7.12.

This feature request is to update it to the newest version.
fields.summary: update atlassian/default-image:2 python version

fields.description:
As an user it would be great if there was any mechanism in place to prevent pushes to Bitbucket if the repository is bigger than a specified size.

As a suggestion, add to the repository settings (which can be controlled only by the admins) a specific size which the repository cannot go beyond. In case that size is reached, the commit is halt and an approval to the current repository administrators is requested. Only if the administrator approves this commit, it will be merged. Discard the changes if the commit is not approved within a specific amount of days.
fields.summary: Create a mechanism to prevent pushes beyond a specific size

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
On a pull request, when a file gets changed, any comments for that file would be marked as outdated.
The problem here is that, when a file gets changed, instead of the behavior above happening, all comments in the PR will be marked as outdated.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open a new PR, with more than 1 file in it
# Add a comment on two or more files in the PR.
# Make a change in one of these files, so that the PR would get updated
# You will be able to see that all files' comments will be marked as outdated, despite only having changed one of those files

h3. Expected Results
Only the file that has been changed would get its comment marked as outdated.

h3. Actual Results
All comments in all files in the pull request get marked as outdated, despite there being no change in these other files.

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: All pull request comments get outdated if a file on the PR has been modified

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Intermittently, comments on Pull requests are marked as outdated, even though they were just created.
This happens both on the old and new pull request experience.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
There are no steps to reproduce, this is intermittent.

h3. Expected Results
Comments in the pull request show up normally when they are not outdated.

h3. Actual Results
Comments in the pull requests are being marked as outdated despite being just created.

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Comments on Pull requests are intermittently created as outdated

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As compared to the [Commit Graph|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1219256/commit-graph-for-bitbucket-server?hosting=server&tab=overview] add-on that is available for Bitbucket Server, the commit graph on Bitbucket Cloud's commits page does not tell the user which branch does the graph represents. 

h3. Suggested Solution
It'll be great if the commit graph on Bitbucket Cloud will be able to show the names of the branches.
fields.summary: The commit graph on Bitbucket Cloud does not show branch name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Bitbucket Cloud*. Using *Bitbucket Server*? See the corresponding suggestion.
{panel}
While git is not an Atlassian-developed tool, it would be good to add a feature into Bitbucket that would allow for tracking of changes when data is placed into a repo that must be removed (data that should never be committed, such as trade-secret information, sensitive or otherwise no-to-be-shared data). 

While there are tools that allow you to remove data, they do not cleanly effect a change and allow for ensuring that the repository can continue to be worked upon easily and there is a loss of information that must be maintained in order to meet audit requirements. 

In other words, the commit and removal of bad data needs to be tracked and stored, and the change in the repo needs to be understood by the tool post-change. Having this automated in Bitbucket would be beneficial for clients and a differentiator for Bitbucket.

Side note: GitLab offers Token Hunter: [https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2019/12/20/introducing-token-hunter/]
fields.summary: Sensitive data removal and tracking for Bitbucket

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Pipelines YAML validator fails to detect an error with global YAML anchors in place as shown below:
{code:java}
.set_varibles: &setvar |
  export var='value'
 
pipelines:
  pull-requests:
    '**':
      - step:
          size: 2x
          name: test_app
          script:
            - ...
              
          services:
            - docker 
     
   definitions:
      services:
        docker:
          memory: 7128                   {code}
 

Observe, 'pipelines' and 'definitions' sections are not on the same level. This YAML configuration doesn't detect any error on [https://bitbucket-pipelines.atlassian.io/validator]
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Copy the config above to [https://bitbucket-pipelines.atlassian.io/validator]
 # Try removing the following section and observe,

{code:java}
.set_varibles: &setvar |
  export var='value'{code}

I am unable to find the issue with other sections like branches, tags, pull-requests not being indented and it only appears with major sections 'pipelines' and 'definitions'.
h3. Expected Results

YAML validator should ideally detect errors related to indentation even with global YAML anchors.
h3. Actual Results

YAML validator fails to detect errors with global YAML anchors in place.
h3. Workaround
 * Comment out all the Global YAML sections and look for errors. If nothing found, uncomment and commit the changes.
fields.summary: Pipelines YAML validator fails to detect errors with global YAML anchors

fields.description:
As a repository admin,

I need to be able to control which branches run pipelines

So that I can prevent security vulnerabilities

 

Example use case:

My organization has a rogue developer that wants to expose private IP by publicly npm publishing a repository. This could be prevented if:
 # Branch permissions prevented the developer from committing directly to master (exists in bitbucket)
 # Pipeline job execution permissions were configured to ensure that only the master branch ever executed, or that suspicious builds were approvable.
fields.summary: Lock down which branches can run bitbucket pipelines CI

fields.description:
We have hundreds of repositories and adding default reviewers to every single one, or every single time when creating a new repository is a pain... Here's what I suggest.
 # Allow creating user groups dedicated as code reviewers.
 # Allow a global, project, target branch and repository setting to use a default user group of code reviewers.
 ## We use projects as brands to separate clients, thus separating development teams and following our legal process of client security by not mixing data.
 # Update the current default reviewers setting to choose 1 or multiple user groups of code reviewers.
 # The branch permissions dialog should inherit the user groups if default reviewers is selected or allow global user group.
 ## Code reviewer user groups may need to have default permission to 'merge via pull request' or at least figure out an updated UX solution for automation.

This would save so much time. Please vote!
fields.summary: Manage Default Reviewers as a User Group.

fields.description:
1 .  Pass flags to commands : user should be able to pass diff flags while running the same command integrated by him, there will be by default flag and also if he wants to pass diff flag he should be able to do this
2. Pass environment variables in pipeline
fields.summary: Integrate UI for CI/CD pipeline

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As of now, users can only transfer repository ownership through each individual repository's settings page.
This will be a hassle/time-consuming for users who has hundreds of repository which needed to be transfer/combine to/with another account.

h3. Suggested Solution
# It will be best to have the options on UI to allow users to bulk transfer repositories from account to another account easily.
# _or_ API Endpoint to allow users to create a script to proceed with the transfer. [BCLOUD-5333|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-5333]
fields.summary: Options to Bulk transfer repositories to another account/workplace
Close issue across repo

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Transferring a repository from a personal account to a team account which the user have "repository creation" access enables the user to accept the repository transfer.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a repository on your personal account
 # Grant the account which is transferring the repository "repository creation" access (write or read access)
 # Transfer the repository
 #* Note that you are shifted to the administrator repository transfer page instead of receiving the pop up stating the transfer request has been sent.

h3. Expected Results
Non-administrator users to not be able to accept repository transfer.

h3. Actual Results
Non_administrator users are able to accept repository transfer.

h3. Workaround

Restrict the repository creation or administrator access.
fields.summary: Transferring a repository from a personal account to a team account which the user have "repository creation" access enables the user to accept the repository transfer

fields.description:
This is a feature that is available on the old Pull request experience but it's not on the new one. When hovering the mouse over users in a pull request in the old PR experience, the following shows up:
 !image-2020-02-03-18-42-21-570.png|thumbnail! 

The same isn't true for the new PR experience:
 !image-2020-02-03-18-43-21-158.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Show the "<user> updated this pull request " tooltip again on the new pull request experience

fields.description:
When adding or removing Pull request reviewers, it's not possible to see when these changes happened, and who has performed those changes.

This feature request is to add the ability to see Pull request reviewer changes on the activity section of pull requests.
fields.summary: Add reviewer edits on the pull request activity section

fields.description:
This feature request is to show the actual error message of issues that happen in Bitbucket Cloud instead of showing a "something went wrong" error.
This will allow users to know what's going on with their repository in a much more transparent fashion, and would allow users to troubleshoot issues whenever possible.
fields.summary: Change "something went wrong" messages to provide insights on how to fix the issue

fields.description:
It would be good to have the ability to run after scripts for stopped builds for cases where a Pipeline build triggers steps that start a deployment to a server, for example.

Once a build is stopped on Bitbucket Pipelines, it would be good to be able to automatically trigger steps to cancel the build on the server too. The after-script function seems to be the best approach for this.
fields.summary: Run after-script scripts for stopped builds

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If you have a PR and deleted the target branch then access the PR on BB UI in New Pull Request experience, the page will give the error "We stumbled a bit here". Also, there is no option to decline the PR in New Pull Request experience.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create or use an existing PR
 # Delete the target branch of the PR
 # Access the PR via Bitbucket Cloud UI in New Pull Request experience

h3. Expected Results

The PR will load on Bitbucket Cloud UI with options to merge/delete the Pull request
h3. Actual Results

The PR is not loading after deleting the target branch on Bitbucket Cloud UI in New Pull Request experience

Page Error:
{noformat}
We stumbled a bit here.

Try again or contact support if this keeps happening.
{noformat}
h3. Workaround (use one of the below option)
 * Enable Old Pull Request experience by following the given below instructions. You should be able to view and decline Pull request using New Pull Request experience
 ** Select Avatar on lower left corner in Bitbucket UI
 ** Select _*Bitbucket Labs*_ option from menu
 ** Enable _*Old pull request experience Lab*_ feature

 * Use the below API 2.0 endpoint to decline Pull request.
{code:java}
/2.0/repositories/{workspace}/{repo_slug}/pullrequests/{pull_request_id}/decline
{code}
API Documentation: [Here|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pullrequests/%7Bpull_request_id%7D/decline]
fields.summary: Deleting the target branch of a PR will break the PR on BB UI

fields.description:
Currently, the [Overview page|https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/overview] only displays open Pull Requests to be reviewed and Pull Requests create by the logged user.

We would like to have the option to filter these Pull Requests and include Merged and Declined Pull Request, as after being merged, the Pull Request disappears from the Overview page, making it hard to keep track of the approved changes.
fields.summary: Overview page - Pull Request display

fields.description:
As an user, I would like to be able to add comments on the side-by-side diff view in Pull Request page. 
User has reported this functionality is available at Github and its pretty useful while code reviewing.
fields.summary: Add the option to comment on side-by-side diff view

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When first loading commit page after logging in/come up from inactivity, commits page does not load branches and tags information

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log in to bitbucket
 # After some time of inactivity, go to a repository and click commits

h3. Expected Results
# branches and tags information for the commit list are loaded for each commit

h3. Actual Results
# branches and tags information for the commit list does not load

h3. Workaround
Click other menu and back to the commits, then it is loaded.
fields.summary: Commit page does not shows branches and tags information sometimes on first load

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Using @ mention within pull request comments sometimes shows a non-related person.
This happens depending on the number of characters typed after the mention.
The behavior gets worse depending on the size of the pull request.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Grant multiple people with access to the repository
 # Open a Pull Request
 # Use the @ mention feature and you will notice that sometimes:
 #* The mentioned text does not have anything to do with the results. 
 #* The correct results take some time to populate

h3. Expected Results
@ mention would populate the results fast and correctly.

h3. Actual Results
@ mention populate previous results and/or take some time to populate the correct ones.

h3. Workaround

As workaround users have to re-write the mention and/or wait some time until the correct results are populated. The users might also need to write a substantial amount of characters for the @ mention to recognize the correct users.
fields.summary: Using @ mention within pull request comments sometimes shows a non-related person

fields.description:
Hello,
Please, add the set o configuration below on the notifications part of Bitbucket Pull Requests:

* A new pull request has been opened that the user tagged as a reviewer
* A comment has been made on a pull request that the user a reviewer on
* An approval has been put on a pull request that the user a reviewer on
* A pull request that the user a reviewer on has been merged.

Thank you.
fields.summary: New set of configuration on notifications.
Would like to create and host jar packages from Bitbucket

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Merging a pull request with "Close branch" feature enabled from a forked repository where the merging user only has read access throws an error

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a forked repository and open it
# Commit a file from a non-master branch
# Create a pull request to the main repository from the forked repository
# Select "Close branch" 
# On the main repository with an user who only has read access or none access to the forked repository, click merge.

On the backend, this is the error seen:
"pre-receive hook exited with 1 You're not allowed to write to this repository."

h3. Expected Results
The pull request would be merged and the source branch would be closed with no error messages seen.

h3. Actual Results
The pull request merge the commit but it stays opened, the user sees an error and the source branch is not closed.

h3. Workaround

1- Grant the user merging the pull request write or above access on the forked repository
2- Or unselect close branch while creating the pull request.
fields.summary: Merging a pull request with "Close branch" feature enabled from a forked repository where the merging user only has read access throws an error

fields.description:
As a developer reviewing pull requests, I want to add comments on files that I'm looking at in split-view.

*IS*

You need to unify views to add a comment to a specific row.

*SHOULD*

Allow commenting on lines while staying in split-view.
fields.summary: Allow commenting in split-view

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Server, I am able to quickly navigate the file structure, expanding directories and clicking files to view changes on the left (stable interface) and the diffs are shown on the right.

On Bitbucket Cloud, if I click on any of the files changed, it autoscrolls me down to the file, and I have to scroll all the way back up to see the file view again.

Please consider bringing the file control on Bitbucket Server, into Bitbucket Cloud.
fields.summary: The UX to view files when viewing specific commit information is poor

fields.description:
As a reviewer, I would expect to be able to:
 # Click on a PR
 # Scroll down to review changes
 # In any 'change' panel click on 'Blame' without having to 'Open File'

Bitbucket Server got this functionality right!  I don't want to exit my view to see Blame data, as Bitbucket Cloud proposes with its alternate UX of Open File, Annotate.
fields.summary: Where is the 'Blame' functionality in PRs?

fields.description:
Where is the "Needs Work" button?  This feature where you don't decline a PR, but flag it as needing refinement is very important.  

 

In a team setting, it is a great indicator on the main view that a PR had been modified after your last review (since needs work, would get reset).
fields.summary: Bitbucket Cloud PRs - add the 'needs work' concept.

fields.description:
The view on Bitbucket Cloud is incredibly cluttered.  It's working so hard to jam everything on one page, and the result is an inferior UX.

Being able to quickly scan commit activity is of critical importance in a team setting, but Bitbucket Cloud makes this painful.
 # The *Overview* tab on Server allows me to rapidly see activity, listing commits, key PR comments, as well as first lines in commit comments.  To find this on cloud, the UX is a bit more messy, and we lose data.  I have to scroll down alllll the way on the right hand side to get an overview, and at that, I get much less information than on Server.
 # The *Commits* page has no analog in Bitbucket Cloud.  What a loss.  Give us a view/tab such as this one please!
fields.summary: Better commit-level visibility - as is done in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
How can I quickly filter files like I can on the Diff tab on Bitbucket server? That little dropdown above the file list:
 * Show diff of (all changes in PR)
 * Diff since last review
 * Individual commits
 * I can also use the little search field to filter files by content.
fields.summary: Diffs on Bitbucket Cloud seem vastly inferior to Diffs on Bitbucket Server.

fields.description: What happened to clicking "Like" on comments? Not critical, but it was an easy way to voice support for someone's claim or opinion.
fields.summary: Bring the Like functionality on Bitbucket Server, onto Bitbucket Cloud
